title: How often do authors get paid their royalties for self published book? - Quora

response.answer_text: If it’s truly self-published, they don’t get royalties. Royalties are a payment a publisher makes to the author. But if the author is the publisher, there’s no additional step. Sales go directly to the author/publisher. That said, the author/publisher likely doesn’t own their own storefront. In those rare cases where it’s the author actually handling the money from the buyer, the money from a sale goes straight into their pocket. More often, though, there’s a retailer in the way, whether it’s the corner bookstore or Amazon. In that case, there are a couple of models. For physical books, the retailer (or a distributor) pays up front for product and keeps the sale price (with various complicated exceptions). For many electronic platforms, the retailer pays the author/publisher a cut of sales on a contractually agreed-upon schedule. I gather that monthly is pretty common. But those are sales, not royalties.

Amazon pays my royalties monthly for all sales earned in the previous month (ie, I get paid royalties in early February for sales earned in January). And of course, I get paid immediately for sales earned through my own shop front. My commission contracts with brick-and-mortar bookshops for print sales vary by commission contract (40% royalty with Net 60 terms is most common; YMMV), but my return from those sales is negligible after shipping costs (which I have to pay myself to maintain a physical inventory). I write these copies off as promotional costs rather than account them as unit sales. You may (and probably should) handle similar circumstances differently than I do. I should have set my cover price for print higher if I wanted to see a profit from these arrangements; I simply didn’t think of it at the time, and now that I know better, I don’t want to change my online print pricing (deliberately low to facilitate impulse purchases), and I don’t want to pay extra or burn another ISBN just to run separate inventory copies with different pricing for commission sales purposes.
